age: 55. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Ibuprofen / Penicillins / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / 
Latex
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
rapidly progressive syndrome of
back and radiating leg pain with progressive lower extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar posterior decompression

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ generally healthy
male who presented with a rapidly progressive syndrome of
back and radiating leg pain with progressive lower extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk.
Due to the severity of symptoms, the progressive nature of
his neurological deficit, the severity of his stenosis, and
the natural history of this disorder, he elected to undergo
surgical treatment.
 
Past Medical History:
see H+P
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
see H+P
 
Physical Exam:
see H+P
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
3. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*75 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*90 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
5. finasteride 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
6. tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime).
Disp:*60 Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
7. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.)(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
back and
radiating leg pain, in the setting of progressive lower 
extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of ability to walk.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

Physical Therapy:
Ambulate as tolerated. 
Treatments Frequency:
Keep dressing clean and dry
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 55-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a rapidly progressive syndrome of back and radiating leg pain, progressive lower extremity weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk. He underwent a lumbar posterior decompression procedure without complication. The patient has a history of allergies to Ibuprofen, Penicillins, Sulfa, and Latex. His past medical history is significant for spinal stenosis, and he has a family history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, docusate sodium, oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, finasteride, and tamsulosin. He was advised to follow a normal diet, avoid lifting heavy objects, and to ambulate as tolerated. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and to take his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent living donor renal transplant with 6 
___ double J ureteral stent. Of note the venous anastomosis 
was redone intra op. The kidney was making urine. Surgeon was 
Dr. ___. Please refer to operative note further details. 
He received induction immunosuppression which consisted of ATG, 
Cellcept and Solu-Medrol. Prograf was started. 

Postop overnight, urine output decreased to 35 and SBP was in 
low ___. Normal saline boluses were given without much change. 
5% albumin was then given with gradual increase in urine output 
and SBP to low 100s. He received a 2nd dose of ATG. Prograf was 
held as this was suspected of decreasing urine output. Incision 
was intact with scant serosanguinous drainage. Abdomen was 
non-distended. He experienced a little bit of nausea and was 
given Zofran. Urine output gradually increased to 150ml/hr. He 
continued to receive ___ NS cc/cc urine output replacements. 

On postop day 2, urine output continued to average 210 to 100 
cc. IV fluid replacements were decreased to a maintenance rate D 
___ at 100cc. Vital signs were stable. A 3rd dose of ATG 
(125mg each dose) was administered and Prograf was started at 
2mg bid.  Diet was advanced to regular, however, the patient was 
reluctant to advance given h/o Crohn's and anticipation of 
multiple BMs with regular food. By postop day 5, he was taking 
solid food but c/o multiple loose stools. Imodium 2mg daily was 
started with decrease in stool output. On postop day 6, urine 
output was ~ 2 liter per day. Creatinine was down to 1.9. 
Incision was intact and without drainage. He was taking 
Oxycodone for pain with good relief and was ambulating 
independently. Medication teaching went well. Dapsone was 
started ___ PCP prophylaxis given sulfa allergy 
precluding Bactrim. G6PD was 11.8. 

Of note, Prograf level increased to a high of 18.4 on ___. ___ 
dose of Prograf was held and prograf 3mg was given in am ___. 
Trough level was 7.0 that day and dose was increased to 4mg bid. 
He was instructed to have trough level drawn at ___ Lab 
on ___ and ___. Cellcept was well tolerated. Steroids were 
tapered off. 

He was discharged to home in stable condition.

lisinopril 2.5mg', nephrocaps

Please call the Transplant office ___ if you have any

-you will need to have labs drawn tomorrow, ___ then

target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 51-year-old male who underwent a living non-related renal transplant due to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) caused by medication toxicity and chronic dehydration. He has a history of Crohn's disease, which was treated with total colectomy and ileoanal pullthrough 20 years ago. He has been on hemodialysis since then. The patient has allergies to sulfa, penicillins, and Asacol. His past medical history includes ESRD, interstitial nephritis, and Asacol on HD via RIJ tunnel cath. 

During his hospital stay, the patient received induction immunosuppression and underwent a successful transplant with a living donor. He experienced some complications, including decreased urine output and low blood pressure, which were managed with fluid replacement and medication adjustments. The patient was discharged with a stable condition and was instructed to follow up with the transplant office and to have regular lab tests. His medications at discharge included acetaminophen, dapsone, famotidine, mycophenolate mofetil, nystatin, amlodipine, oxycodone, tacrolimus, and valganciclovir. ||endoftext||

Her neurological problems began when her mother noted psychomotor slowing, short-term memory problems, and inability to tolerate stress.

The patient's allergies include Ampicillin, Penicillins, and Morphine Hcl. She has no known adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is recurrent EBV-driven CNS lymphoma, which is being treated with HD-MTX. She has undergone several cycles of HD-MTX and has had a stable brain MRI.

The patient's procedures performed include a stereotaxic brain biopsy and CyberKnife radiosurgery.

The patient's medications prescribed at discharge include leucovorin, anti-emetics, and mycophenolate. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Resume all home medications. Seek immediate medical attention 
for fever >101.5, chills, increased redness, swelling, bleeding 
or discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, 
difficulty breathing, severe headache, increasing neurological 
deficit, or anything else that is troubling you. No strenuous 
exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment, at least. 
Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain 
medications. Call your surgeon to make follow up appointment. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Her chief complaint was abdominal pain, which was likely secondary to increased ascites. She had a diagnostic paracentesis, which was negative for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). She was given zofran and morphine and admitted to medicine for further evaluation.

The patient has a past medical history of EtOH abuse, cirrhosis, and ascites. She has allergies to epinephrine. She was prescribed several medications, including lasix, spironolactone, azithromycin, and levofloxacin, but was unsure why she was prescribed these medications.

The patient's physical exam revealed a firm, distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave and diffusely tender to palpation. She had no organomegaly appreciable. Her discharge physical exam revealed a firm, nondistended abdomen with a slight bulge of her umbilical hernia.

The patient's laboratory results showed mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase and normal liver function tests. Her urine analysis showed a trace of protein and a few white blood cells. Her ascites fluid analysis showed a high white blood cell count and a high protein level.

The patient's imaging studies showed low lung volumes with bibasilar atelectasis and a small right pleural effusion on chest X-ray. Her RUQ ultrasound showed a nodular liver with coarsened echotexture and large volume ascites, compatible with hepatic cirrhosis. Her CT abdomen showed a nodular liver with large volume simple ascites and no signs of loculated fluid collection or bowel perforation.

The patient's hospital course was marked by an acute issue of abdominal pain, which was likely secondary to increased ascites. She had a therapeutic paracentesis of 6.5L and had a persisting fluid leak, which was successfully stopped with a suture. She was discharged with improved pain and was advised to follow up with her PCP in a couple of days to repeat her blood pressure and restart diuretics. ||endoftext||

your hair. You may shower before this time using a shower cap to 
cover your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) & 
Senna while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.  
**You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.
If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure 
you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home.

___

||startoftext||The patient is an 81-year-old male who presented with a syncopal episode after a baseball game. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with recent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), chronic heart failure (CHF), end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hypertension (HTN), and atrial fibrillation (Afib). He was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were notable for a temperature of 97.2°F, heart rate of 52 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 151/48 mmHg. His physical examination revealed a bradycardic rhythm, normal rhythm, and a III/VI holosystolic murmur heard throughout the precordium.

Laboratory results showed elevated levels of troponin (0.53 ng/mL) and creatinine (11.0 mg/dL), as well as mild anemia (Hgb 11.3 g/dL). Imaging studies revealed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.0 cm² or less, as well as mild degenerative changes in the ankle joints.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including Eliquis for Afib and metoprolol tartrate for hypertension. He was also advised to undergo evaluation for surgical or transcatheter intervention for severe aortic stenosis, continue hemodialysis three times a week, and consider stopping metoprolol tartrate due to bradycardia.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was marked by a syncopal episode likely due to a vagal episode in the setting of severe aortic stenosis, and he was discharged with recommendations for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

She has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, fibromyalgia, spinal stenosis, chronic pain syndrome, depression, and bilateral cataracts. She has a family history of premature coronary artery disease in her father, who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. 

The patient's allergies include penicillins and ibuprofen. She was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of chest pain and was found to have an 80% stenosis at the bifurcation of the LAD and OM, which was too difficult to stent due to concern for jailing the artery. She also had a 90% lesion to the mid RCA, which was stented with a DES. 

The patient's medications at discharge include ASA, morphine, lopressor, heparin, plavix, and integrallin. Her physical examination was normal, with no signs of chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Her laboratory results showed normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with elevated troponin and creatine kinase levels. 

The patient's diagnosis is two-vessel coronary artery disease, with successful stenting of the mid-RCA with a Cypher DES. Her echocardiogram showed normal left atrial size, left ventricular wall thickness, and regional/global systolic function, with mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. ||endoftext||

CT Abdomen and Pelvis (IV Contrast):
There are small bilateral pleural effusions with associated 
atelectasis. Atelectasis within the lingula is additionally 
noted. 
An amorphous area low attenuation is identified within segment 
IVb of the 
liver. The liver is otherwise unremarkable. The gallbladder, 
spleen, 
pancreas, adrenal glands, and left kidney appear within normal 
limits. The 
kidneys enhance symmetrically and excrete contrast normally. A 
3-cm low- 
attenuation lesion at the lower pole of the right kidney is 
consistent with a simple cyst. Diffuse atherosclerotic disease 
of the infrarenal abdominal aorta is evident.   
There is thickening of the cecum and significant pericecal 
stranding of 
mesenteric fat. Surgical clips at the site of appendectomy are 
noted. No 
evidence of abscess or loculated fluid. A small amount of free 
fluid in this area, which also tracks down into the pelvis is 
seen. Although the distal ileum is not well distended with oral 
contrast, there is a suggestion of bowel wall thickening/edema 
and stranding of the surrounding mesenteric fat. No organized 
fluid collection is evident, however. There is no evidence of 
bowel obstruction as contrast has passed through to the rectum. 
There is no free air within the abdomen. Although the colon is 
not distended, there is a suggestion of diffuse colonic wall 
thickening. 
.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: The rectum, sigmoid colon, 
intrapelvic 
loops of small bowel are unremarkable. A Foley balloon is 
present within a 
decompressed bladder. A small amount of free fluid is evident 
within the 
pelvis. Small, bilateral fat-containing inguinal hernias are 
evident. 
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: There are no suspicious lytic or blastic 
lesions. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Inflammatory process appears to be centered in the ileocecal 
area at the site of recent appendectomy. No organized or 
drainable intra-abdominal fluid collection. Assessment is 
somewhat limited by lack of distal ileal distention with oral 
contrast. A small amount of free fluid and scattered subjacent 
lymph nodes are additionally evident.  
2. Equivocal diffuse colonic wall thickening. This finding 
raises the 
possibility of colitis and and infectious process such as C. 
difficile should be considered.   
3. Small bilateral pleural effusions with associated 
atelectasis. 
.

Mr. ___ was transferred from an outside hospital with 
hypotension, on Levophed with an elevated WBC count of 22.6 on

and differential included infection from recurrent abscesses at 
appendectomy site or C. Diff colitis.  Other etiology considered 
was reaction to CT contrast.  Was started on Vanocmycin, Zosyn 
and Flagyl in the MICU.  He remained hemodynamically stable and 
afebrile and Levophed was stopped on the day of transfer for 
MAP>65, SvO2 72, CVP 6 and good urine output.  CT showed 
inflammation prior appendectomy site without fluid collection.  
Surgery was consulted and did not recommend surgery.  
Gastroenterology was consulted and recommended 48 hours of IV 
antibiotics for presumed GI infection, then 3 weeks of PO 
antibiotics.  Cultures were obtained on ___ from ___ 
___ and showed no growth to date of blood or urine 
cultures.  Blood and urine cultures collected at ___ 
showed no growth to date.  C. Diff X 3 were negative.  The 
patient continued to do well and was trasnferred to the general 
medical floor on ___.  He was continued on IV antibiotics 
and then changed to PO antibiotics on ___.  He was put on 
Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID and Metronidazole 500mg PO TID and 
was discharged with 16 more days of antibiotics.  He will 
___ with his PCP ___ 1 week.  Another possible etiology for 
his symptoms that was considered was anaphylaxis from PO 
contrast from the CT scan, although this was less likely given 
that he has had PO contrast in the past without problems.  We 
recommended that he see an allergist as an outpatient to assess 
the possibility of an allergic reaction to PO contrast.
.

of 133, CKMB 19, Troponin T 0.29 and T-wave inversions in leads 
III and AVL.  Cardiology was called and thought this was likely 
rate-related demand ischemia in the setting of tachycardia due 
to sepsis physiology.  Cardiac enzymes trended down and 
___ ECGs showed no change.  The patient's tachycardia 
improved with IV fluids and antibiotics.  He was asymptomatic 
during his admission.  He was put on telemetry and had no events 
or arrythmias.  An echocardiogram showed global reduced 
function, EF 45% and focal akinesis of basal inferior wall.  
Aspirin 325mg PO qday and Metoprolol 12.5mg PO BID were started 
for NSTEMI.  Cardiology did not recommend heparin or 
anti-platelet agents.  Cardiology recommended a ___ echo 
and cardiologist appointment within 4 weeks after his acute 
illness had resolved. The patient will have this scheduled with 
his primary care doctor.  He remained asymptomatic with no chest 
pain or signs of clinical heart failure.
.

Home

Primary Diagnosis:
1. Sepsis

Secondary Diagnosis:
2. Non-ST Elevation Mycardial Infarction
3. Eosinophilia

 
Discharge Condition:
afebrile, hemodynamically stable, good condition

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with low blood pressure and 
septic shock after having a perforated appendicitis several 
weeks ago.  All your blood cultures were negative.  You were 
admitted to the intensive care unit and improved dramatically on 
antibiotics.  You were initially put on intravenous antibiotics 
and these were changed to oral antibiotics after 72 hours.  You 
experienced some chest pain and blood tests showed that was some 
damange to your heart which was likely from the low blood 
pressure.  You had an echocardiogram which showed some reduced 
function of the heart.  You should see a cardiologist as an 
outpatient as arranged by your primary care doctor and have 
another echocardiogram in 1 month to reassess your heart.

You had a rise in your white blood cell count associated with 
the sepsis.  Your eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, was 
still elevated on discharge.  You should have your blood checked 
in 1 week to assess your white blood count and differential.  
This will be arranged by your primary care doctor.

You should continue to take the antibiotics Ciprofloxacin and 
Metronidazole as prescribed for the next ___ days, even if you 
are feeling well.  You were started on Metoprolol 12.5mg by 
mouth twice a day to help your heart.  You should continue to 
take aspirin.

You should ___ with your primary care doctor next week.  
Your primary care doctor ___ arrange for you to see a 
cardiologist and have a repeat echocardiogram within 1 month.

You should call your doctor or come to the emergency room for 
any fevers > 100, chills, night sweats, cough, shortness of 
breath, chest pain or pressure, numbness in the arm or jaw, 
abdominal pain or bloating, nausea or vomiting, swelling in the 
legs, skin rashes, or any other symptoms that concern you.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with sepsis. He initially presented to the emergency department with perforated appendicitis, which was complicated by an abscess that was drained twice. He was treated with antibiotics and discharged, but two weeks later, he returned to the hospital with sepsis and was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). 

The patient has a history of MRSA abscess on his arm and a previous appendectomy complicated by an abscess. He has no known allergies to drugs. 

On admission, the patient's physical examination revealed an ill-appearing individual with a temperature of 98.4°F, blood pressure of 129/67 mmHg, and a heart rate of 88 beats per minute. His abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended, with well-healed laparoscopic scars. 

Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 24.7, lactate level of 1.8, and troponin level of 0.29. He was treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, levofloxacin, and ceftriaxone, and was started on a norepinephrine drip. 

The patient's diagnosis was sepsis, and he was managed non-surgically. He was discharged with a plan for continued antibiotic therapy and follow-up. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 91-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of cough and fever. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. She was previously admitted to the hospital with a similar condition and was discharged with a course of antibiotics, which she completed. However, her symptoms persisted, and she presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath. On admission, she was febrile with possible early pneumonia on chest X-ray, and she received a dose of ceftriaxone. Her white blood cell count was normal, and her cough was non-productive, so she was not initially treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia. She was started on azithromycin, prednisone, and nebulizers, and her symptoms improved. ||endoftext||

___ with IDDM, possible pyoderma gangrenosum of the perianal

were consulted and recommended wound care. Biopsies and further

developed loose stools with incontinence concerning for C diff 
given history. He was started and discharged with a prescription 
for PO vancomycin.

The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had a left mastectomy with tissue expander 
placement and sentinel node lymph biopsy.  The patient tolerated 
the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received dilaudid PCA with 
good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO cefadroxil for discharge home. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  Her left mastectomy incision was clean and dry, 
flat.  No evidence of hematoma. Her JP drains x 2 with serosang 
fluid.

Discharge Medications:
1. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain: Patient given Rx by Dr. ___ 
previously.  
3. Tylenol ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for fever or pain: Max 12/day. Do not exceed 4gms/4000mgs 
of tylenol per day.  
4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): Over the counter stool softener.  
5. cefadroxil 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day 
for 10 days: Continue while drain remains in place. Refill as 
needed.
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*1*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Breast cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:  
 1. Any left mastectomy/chest dressing should be left in place x 
48 hours after surgery.  
 2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water.  
 3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.  
 4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.  
 5. You may shower daily. No baths until instructed to do so by 
Dr. ___.  When you shower you should secure your drain to a 
laniard or an old pair of stockings tied around your neck so it 
does not hang down.
 6. You should wear your surgibra at all times, except for 
showering.
 .  
 Activity:  
 1. You may resume your regular diet.  
 2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___.  
 .  
 Medications:  
 1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered.  
 2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that 
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do 
not take these meds with additional Tylenol.  
 4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.  
 5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.  
 6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.  
 7.  Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.  
.  
 Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:  
 1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).  
 2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
 
 3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF  
 4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.  
 .  
 Return to the ER if:  
 * If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.  
 * If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.  
 * Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.  
 .  
 DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS  
 You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

She was also advised to resume her regular diet, avoid lifting heavy objects, and take her prescribed medications as ordered. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
On evening of admission, prior fem-fem cutdown site was probed 
by Fellow, who was easily able to palpate the graft. The 
following day, a wound vac was placed on this site. Pt's ray 
incision was packed with iodoform. A LLE ultrasound was obtained 
to evaluate pt's asymmetrical edema and was negative for DVT.   
Pt was seen by her outpt Cardiologist, who recommended a family 
meeting and palliative care consult should pt require a major 
operation. 
On HD 4, a CTA was obtained and demonstrated decreased fluid 
around the graft and an open bypass graft with flow to the foot. 
That night, she tripped on her vac and began to complain of L 
leg pain. 
The following day, pt continued to complain of L leg pain as 
well as SOB. She spiked another fever. Bcx was again sent and a 
CXR demonstrated diffuse interstital edema and small pleural 
effusions. The next day, pt's SOB resolved but her L leg pain 
persisted. Another LLE US found no DVT and a knee x-ray did not 
demonstrate any acute findings. During a vac change, fluid was 
sent and grew E.coli. 
The next day, HD 7, pt's leg pain persisted. Pain meds were 
increased. X-rays from the pelvis down were obtained; they 
showed osteopenia but no fractures or dislocations. A blister 
was noted of the dorsum of her left foot and her antibiotics 
were changed to vancomycin and zosyn (from vanc/cipro/flagyl) to 
better cover streptococcus. The following day the pt's leg pain 
was somewhat improved but the blister on her foot had enlarged. 
A CT scan was obtained and showed edema but no air or abscesses. 

On HD 9, pt's LUE AV graft was unable to be accessed at HD. The 
following day, Interventional Radiology performed a successful 
thrombectomy and venoplasty. On HD 10, a foot XRay was taken, 
which demonstrate a non-displaced ___ metatarsal fracture. 
Podiatry was consulted and recommended no intervention and 
heel-touch only weight bearing status in the left side. The do 
not believe the left foot blister and residual wound is related. 
On HD ___, antibiotic coverage was adjusted to allow for dosing 
only with dialysis, for ease of administration outside the 
hospital. On HD ___ arrangements were made for the patient to be 
discharged to rehab. At the time of discharge, her pain was 
controlled, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding and 
moving her bowels spontaneously. She was sitting up in a chair 
for the large part of the day, but was not yet moving around on 
her own. She should continue physical therapy in rehab to work 
on regaining her mobility.

2. Focal fat seen within the liver.  
3. Mild splenomegaly. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w/ AIDS off HAART for 15 months presents w/ malaise, 
anemia.
.
#HIV: Pt. has had poor reactions to ARV Tx in the past (stopped 
taking because of nausea w/ ritonavir), pt. restarted on ARV w/ 
attention to this. Pt. did well w/ no N/V after taking ritonavir 
at HS. Blood cultures were drawn for bacteria, mycobacteria and 
fungi and were no growth to date on day of D/C. Continued 
dapsone ppx, but considered switching to atovaquone because of 
hemolytic anemia, Hct remained stable so we kept pt. on dapsone.

.
#Abdominal pain: Pt. has Hx of bowel wall ulcer, this seems 
probable as his tenderness is extremely localized, has not been 
progressive. Likely he does not have acute bacterial issue as he 
is non septic and this has been present for a long time. He has 
been scoped before w/ conflicting path results (negative CMV Cx 
but a few inclusions),consider CMV colitis, Consider HSV 
colitis, Consider parasitic ___. Dr. ___ 
performed the endoscopy felt that the ulcer looked like it was 
from CMV and so pt. was empirically started on IV gancyclovir 
and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir after 2 days. The 
abdominal pain seemed to improve slightly day to day. Pt. had 
elevated alk phos, GGT, Tbili so liver U/S was performed and wet 
read was consistent w/ HIV cholangiopathy.
.
#Anemia: Appears to be hemolytic as haptoglobin was decreased to 
<20 and retic count is elevated. Elevated retic count (not 
appropriately elevated given low Hbg) suggests that there is a 
lack of production. He recieved 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct 
increased to above 25 and remained stable after transfusion, on 
day of d/c was 24.9. Likely that he is no longer hemolyzing, but 
unknown whether his marrow is responding at time of d/c. There 
was significant concern that the lack of marrow response 
represented a marrow infiltrative process so a BMB was obtained. 
Results of BMB were pending at D/C.
.
#Fever: Likely OI as pt. has no other focal signs of infection. 
Could be drug fever as pt. recently started on gancyclovir and 
ARV's, the fevers did not appear until the night after the 
gancyclovir was started and continued to wax and wane and he had 
a temperature to 100.8 the night before d/c. CXR, UA, Ucx, Blood 
Cx X3 sets routine Negative so far. Pt. to f/u w/ Dr. ___ 
results of BMB and mycolytic blood cultures.
.
#Fatigue: likely ___ anemia, but may also be due to chronic OI 
and/or HIV wasting syndrome as pt. appeared quite cachectic. 
Nutrition was consulted and recommended ensure supplementation, 
but pt. did not like ensure and made this clear to nutrition, 
ensure was seen unopened on pt.s tray every morning.
.
#Diarrhea: Likely ___ OI, differential is quite wide: crypto, 
giardia, ___, CMV, C. diff. All previous wkup 
was negative in ___.  Likely etiology is an OI which will be 
treated by increasing his CD4 count. Repeat stool studies were 
negative for o/p, ___, crypto, giardia, cyclospora.
.
#Hyponatremia: Possibly secondary to diarrhea with free water 
replacement or SIADH from chronic pain. Most likelly from 
diarrhea. Urine lytes, Cr, Osm inconclusive for SIADH vs. volume 
depletion. FeNa was 1.6. Pt. remained asymptomatic and recieved 
no specific treatment.
.
#Elevated alk phos: Likely bile duct source as GGT also 
elevated. Pt. also complaining of RUQ pain and tenderness, has 
previous history of U/S which showed cholelithiasis. Liver U/S 
did not show stones in duct, wet read was consistent with HIV 
cholangiopathy.

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 65-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure. She has a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), orthostatic hypotension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). She has allergies to penicillins and oxybutynin. The patient's chief complaint was hypoxia, dyspnea, productive cough, and congestion, which she experienced for the past two days. She was previously intubated and had a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. She was referred to the emergency department for stoma closure and was found to have tachypnea, rhonchorous lungs, and a stoma site. The patient was given various medications, including albuterol, ipratropium bromide, and cefepime. She was also given oxygen therapy and had a flutter valve inserted. The patient's physical examination revealed clear lungs, regular heart rate and rhythm, and normal abdominal examination. The patient's laboratory results showed anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP). Imaging studies revealed extensive atelectasis in the lower lungs, which could not exclude a superimposed pneumonia. The patient was discharged with a tracheostomy mask and speaking valve, and was advised to use a flutter valve and oxygen therapy. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Brain Tumor

Surgery
 You underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your brain 

 Please keep your incision dry until your sutures are removed. 
 You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
 It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
 Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
 We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
 You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
 No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
 If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
 No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
 Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
 You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instructions. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 
 You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
 You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
 You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
 You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
 Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
 Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
 Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
 Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
 Nausea and/or vomiting
 Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
 Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
 Seizures
 Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
 Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
 Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
 Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
 Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
 Sudden severe headaches with no known reason
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Her vital signs were stable, and she was able to walk and sit in a chair. The patient's discharge plan included follow-up with the endoscopist and further management of her pain and condition. ||endoftext||

contrast is seen in the ascending colon and there is air and

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old male with past medical history of diabetes 
type 2 uncontrolled complicated by neuropathy, Crohn's disease 
s/p ileocecectomy and multiple laparotomies for SBO, chronic 
diarrhea and recurrent pseudo-obstructions prompting venting 
G-Jtube, admitted ___ w diarrhea and abdominal distention 
thought to represent partial small bowel obstruction, with long 
hospital course course notable for intermittent intolerance of 
tube feeds, subsequently requiring initiation of TPN after long 
discussions with patient and GI service, now tolerating well, 
having regular bowel movements without signs of obstruction or 
diarrhea, discharged home with TPN; 

ACTIVE ISSUES
# Intermittent Small Bowel Obstructions / Diarrhea / Abdominal 
pain / Crohn's Disease / Small Intestine Bacterial Overgrowth - 
On presentation, the patient had acutely worsened diffuse 
chronic abdominal pain on presentation. Subsequent workup 
supported multifactorial causes including likely intermittent 
partial small bowel obstructions, osmotic diarrhea from dietary 
indiscretions (eating lots of starburst candies) and Crohn's 
disease.  Initial concern was for SBO. He had a CT with PO and 
IV contrast that showed mild ileus. However, there was some 
thickening of the bowel wall that initially raised concern for 
Crohn's flare (on subsequent revised read, the thickening was 
deemed artifact). Subsequently, he had a colonoscopy that showed 
ulceration at his colonic-colonic anastomosis with biopsies 
showing terminal ileum inflammation. Given that the results were 
suggestive of Crohn's, the patient was started on budesonide 9mg 
PO daily. Furthermore, in working up his diarrhea, which 
improved with no oral intake, he was found to have a stool Osm 
gap of 357-2*(70+24.3) = 168, which suggested an osmotic 
diarrhea. When tube feed was initiated (see below), his diarrhea 
worsened to over 10 times overnight. Eventually, given that he 
had a borderline SIBO breath test in the past, he was started on 
rifaximin empirically for SIBO treatment. When he started TPN 
(see below), his diarrhea improved to 4 BMs per day.

# Acute Protein Calorie Malnutrition - Patient with > 20lb weigh 
loss over last 6 months.  He had intermittent symptoms as above, 
but failed trials of starting on tube feed on 4 separate 
attempts due to abdominal pain, distension and diarrhea.  He was 
tried on several formulations without improvement. Patient 
educated on risks/benefits of TPN.  Ultimately, he was started 
on TPN via R PICC access. He will eventually need consideration 
for a Port-A-Cath if he is to continue TPN long term--given the 
uncertainty about how long he would require TPN, port not placed 
this admission.  He tolerated TPN well with no electrolyte 
abnormalities and signs of refeeding syndrome. He was giving 
thiamine intermittently throughout his hospitalization with 
tubefeed and TPN. 

# Dysphagia | Esophageal Spasm - The patient reported 
significant swallowing issues during his stay and refused to 
take in POs, including pills. He had a barium swallow study that 
showed findings consistent with diffuse esophageal spasm. GI 
consult team wanted to follow up with manometry testing as 
outpatient before starting therapy. Fortunately, his symptoms 
improved during the course of his stay, and he requested 
trialing PO food and was able to tolerate small amount of POs on 
discharge.

# Chronic Back Pain | Chronic Abdominal Pain - Due to NPO 
status, he was given IV hydromorphone in place of his PO regimen 
at home for the most part of his stay. The patient requested on 
multiple occasions to speak with the Pain specialists here. The 
Pain Consult team saw the patient and recommended uptitration of 
gabapentin to 900mg TID for chronic pain and maintaining his 
home narcotics regimen. The team discussed with the patient that 
his abdominal pain can possibly be attributed to his high 
narcotics requirement leading to narcotics bowel syndrome. The 
patient was very reluctant to the idea of decreasing his pain 
medications, stating that without them, he cannot have a normal 
life and wants to have a life. He was discharged on his home 
regimen, but with the understanding that if abdominal symptoms 
should recur or persist, he may need to consider downtitration 
of opiates. He reported needing more hydromorphone despite 
having filled a recent prescription for a 1 month supply only 2 
weeks prior to admission.

CHRONIC ISSUES
# Hypertension: The patient's BPs had been well controlled 
throughout his admission up until the last part of his stay, 
when he had elevated BPs to 180s at times. His home labetalol 
regimen was uptitrated to 400mg TID from 300mg TID. It's 
possible this is due to switching from IV hydromorphone to PO.

# COPD: No symptoms while hospitalized. He continued home 
inhaler regimen. 

# Diabetes Mellitus: Complicated by neuropathy. Patient endorsed 
neuropathic pain in his feet. He continue home Gabapentin liquid 
as tolerated.

# Coronary Artery Disease: He had no symptoms. He continued ASA 
and labetalol. Lisinopril was DC'ed as outpatient due to labile 
blood pressures.
  
# Anxiety/Depression: The patient's overall mood was stable but 
he became tearful at times when discussing his chronic illness. 
He continue home lorazepam, buproprion, and buspirone.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- TPN: Will need ongoing evaluation of his nutritional 
requirement.
- Access: Patient currently has a PICC for TPN administration. 
If he will be on TPN for a long time, please consider placing a 
Port for longer term access.
- Antibiotics: Will need to continue taking rafaximin 550mg PO 
TID for 7 days, until ___.
- Pain: Patient has been having ongoing issues with abdominal 
pain. His gabapentin was uptitrated to 900mg TID per the 
recommendations of Pain consult team.
- Hypertension: Patient's BP was low earlier during stay but 
became elevated towards the end (160s), likely due to no longer 
receiving IV pain medication. His labetalol was uptitrated to 
400mg TID. Please consider another antihypertensive agent since 
his heart rate is only ___ at discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ after having increasing difficulty 
with maintaining nutrition at home and increasing abdominal 
pain. We performed a CT scan that ruled out a small bowel 
obstruction. We performed a colonoscopy that showed inflammation 
at your anastamosis site, for which we are treating you with 
budesonide, an oral steroid. Furthermore, for your difficulty 
swallowing, we found some signs of esophageal dysmotility on a 
barium study. Fortunately, your symptoms improved without any 
intervention.

Despite our best attempts to start nutrition with tube feed, we 
were unsuccessful. Therefore, we eventually decided to start 
total parenteral nutrition, which you will need to continue on 
until you are able to better tolerate eating by mouth. Last, we 
tried to optimize your diarrhea by trialing you on an 
antibiotics to treat bacteria overgrowth in the small bowel.

Your blood pressure was elevated towards the end of your 
hospitalization. We increased your home dose of labetalol, and 
you will need to follow up with Dr. ___ further 
titration.

Please check your finger sticks at home so that we can monitor 
your glucose level and determine whether you need insulin in 
your TPN.

It was a pleasure to take care of you. We wish you the best!

Sincerely,

Your ___ Care Team

||startoftext||The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of weight loss. He has a history of Crohn's disease, multiple laparotomies, and short gut syndrome, which has led to complications such as intermittent small bowel obstruction and dependence on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He also has a history of chronic abdominal pain, depression, and anxiety. On admission, his physical examination revealed a diffusely tender abdomen with mild rebound tenderness, and his laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil count, and C-reactive protein. He was diagnosed with a possible small bowel obstruction and was treated with nebulizer therapy and oral steroids. At discharge, his vital signs were stable, and his physical examination revealed a mild firmness and diffusely tender abdomen. His laboratory results showed improvement in his white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, but his albumin and calcium levels remained low. He was prescribed medications for his chronic pain and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

Note: The patient's allergies and adverse reactions are listed as codeine and penicillins. ||endoftext||

___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a 
new ileostomy placement is dehydration. The output from the 
stoma is stool from the small intestine and the water content is 
very high. The stool is no longer passing through the large

into the body and the stool becomes formed. ___ must measure 
your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output from

symptoms of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon

notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the

may eat a modified regular diet with your new ileostomy.

||startoftext||The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. She had a history of recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer and had undergone multiple surgeries and chemotherapy treatments. She was initially diagnosed with stage IIC ovarian cancer and had received carboplatin and Taxol therapy until she developed a carboplatin allergy. She was then switched to Doxil and later started on Arimidex. She had been stable until she developed abdominal pain, concern for acute appendicitis, and underwent laparoscopic evaluation, which revealed several carcinoma implants along both hemidiaphragms, the right lobe of the liver, and the lower abdomen on the sigmoid colon and appendix.

The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy with extended right colectomy and end ileostomy. She was found to have small bowel pneumatosis and was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for sepsis. She was also found to have rising CA-125 levels and was initiated on carboplatin therapy. However, she developed a carboplatin allergy and was switched to Doxil.

The patient's past medical history is significant for recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer, osteopenia, and a family history of CAD and ovarian cancer. Her physical exam revealed abdominal tenderness, absent bowel sounds, and a Foley catheter in place draining clear urine.

The patient's discharge medications included vanc/zosyn, and her discharge labs showed elevated WBC count, AST, and ALT levels. Her imaging studies revealed a partially rim-enhancing fluid collection within the anterior midline abdomen, no findings of bowel obstruction or leak, and bibasilar atelectasis with small left pleural effusion.

In summary, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer who underwent exploratory laparotomy with extended right colectomy and end ileostomy due to abdominal pain and concern for acute appendicitis. She was found to have small bowel pneumatosis and was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for sepsis. She was also found to have rising CA-125 levels and was initiated on carboplatin therapy, but developed a carboplatin allergy and was switched to Doxil. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 75-year-old female who was admitted with a chief complaint of left thigh bleeding. She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, COPD, and prior DVT. She was previously treated with Lovenox and was admitted to the hospital with an arterial bleed into her thigh, which required embolization of the left medial femoral circumflex artery. The patient's bleeding resolved with the application of Surgicel and direct pressure, but she experienced recurrent bleeding when she got up to use the bathroom. A CT scan revealed a fluid collection with surrounding stranding, consistent with an abscess. The patient was treated with antibiotics and was advised to remain non-weightbearing. She was also prescribed medications including acetaminophen, furosemide, levothyroxine, and valacyclovir.

The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, COPD, and prior DVT. She also has a history of breast cancer, asthma, and ocular herpes. Her social history is significant for a motor vehicle accident in which she believes part of her skull was removed.

The patient's physical examination revealed a firm hematoma in her left upper thigh, as well as a chronic appearing wound with no active bleeding. Her vital signs were stable, and her laboratory results showed a decrease in her hemoglobin level. The patient was advised to remain non-weightbearing and to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old right handed ___ driver with an unknown medical 
history was found in his truck confused by the police on the 
morning of admission. According to the patient, he has nausea 
last night, which continued until this morning. He also had a 
bifrontal throbbing headache, which continues to be present. He 
is not sure whether the headache came on suddenly. He does not 
know why he was found in his truck with a laceration above his 
right eye, and a dislocated right middle finger.  It was 
hypothesized he may have had a seizure resulting in mild trauma 
and possible contra-coup injury (right frontal trauma with left 
posterior temporal contusion).  Other possibilities included 
arteriovenous malformation or underlying mass.  The patient was 
admitted to the neurology ICU for further management.
.

.
Neuro; The patient was loaded on keppra upon admission and 
continued at 1000 mg bid.  He was monitored initially with q1h 
neurochecks.  His systolic blood pressure was maintained between 
100-140 without intervention.  A repeat CT head showed a stable 
intraparenchymal and small subdural hematoma.  MRI brain showed 
no evidence of underlying mass.  A CTA showed no sign of 
vascular malformation.  The patient will undergo repeat MRI 
brain with and without contrast in ___ weeks for further 
evaluation of his hemorrhage.  He will continue on keppra at 
1000 mg bid for at least six months.  The patient was 
transferred to the neurology floor on HD#2.  There he was 
evaluated by ___ who found that he was stable and able to 
ambulate without assistance. A repeat head CT on ___ showed no 
change in the intraparenchymal or subdural bleeds. He did not 
have any seizure activity while in house.
.
MSK; The patient was found to have a dislocation of his right 
middle finger which was subsequently reduced. This was splinted 
and did not cause him significant pain
.
CV/Pulm/Renal/GI: the patient was stable from a cardiac, 
pulmonary, renal and GI standpoint. He tolerated a regular diet 
without issues, he made adequate urine and did not have any 
desaturations.

On HD 5 the patient felt well and a repeat head CT showed no 
evolving process. He was anxious to return home to ___ 
as his family had finally arrived in ___. He will take all 
hospital documents with him and tranfer his care down to PA near 
his family. At the time of discharge he was ambulating without 
assistance, tolerating a regular diet but did have some 
persistent confusion. However, he and his family understood the 
gravity of his problem and certified that he would arrange 
follow up care with neurology and neurosurgery upon his return 
to ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the 
gynecology service after undergoing and IV guided drainage of a 
tuboovarian abscess noted on her left adnexa. Please see the 
operative report for full details.

Her immediate post op course was complicated by low grade fevers 
on post-operative day 1 and 2 and IV antibiotics were broadened 
to include gentamycin, clindamycin, and ampicillin. On post-op 
day 2, patient had an elevated WBC with increasing left shift 
and repeat pelvic ultrasound and CT pelvis with contrast was 
performed. Imaging was notable for a decreased left adnexal 
fluid collection of 3cm (decreased from 6cm on admission) and a 
new right rim-enhancing 1.3cm and 0.9 collection on the right 
adnexa. Interventional radiology was re-consulted but given 
improvement of WBC count and clinical improvement, additional 
drainage deferred. On post-op day 3, she was transitioned to PO 
levofloxacin and metronidazole. Patient remained afebrile and 
felt subjectively improved. 

During her stay she was noted to have negative gonorrhea, 
chlamydia, trichomoniasis, and HIV tested. Tumor markers were 
noted to be within normal limits. The fluid drained from her 
left adnexal mass grew no microorganisms and urine cultures were 
negative. 

On post-operative day 3, she was voiding spontaneously, her diet 
was advanced without difficulty, and she was transitioned to 
oral pain medications and oral antibiotocs.She was then 
discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up 
scheduled.

day Disp #*27 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Atenolol 100 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Losartan Potassium 50 mg PO DAILY  
6.  MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 500 mg PO DAILY

Home

Tubo-ovarian abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service for treatment of 
tubo-ovarian abscess. You were started on antibiotics and also 
underwent an ___ guided drainage of a fluid collection in your 
abdomen. We feel that it is now safe to discharge 

Please follow these instructions:
- General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Vascular Surgery Service for 
evaluation and treatment.  On ___, the patient underwent left 
carotid endarterectomy, which went well without complication 
(reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a 
brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the 
floor NPO, on IV fluids, with a foley catheter, and oxycodone 
for pain control.  The patient was hemodynamically stable.

Neuro: The patient received oxycodone and tylenol with good 
effect and adequate pain control.  

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. An artertial 
line was initially placed for close blood pressure monitoring. 
He was continued on all home medications including beta-blocker. 
Home ace-inhibitor was restarted POD1.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.

GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well 
tolerated.  Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, 
and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary.  Electrolytes were 
routinely followed, and repleted when necessary. Foley catheter 
was removed at midnight POD0 and the patient voided. Following 
foley catheter placement, hematuria was noted. It cleared over 
the postoperative course. Urology recommended the patient be 
seen by his outpatient urologist given his history of bladder 
cancer. This was commnunicated to the patient and his wife and 
daughter directly.

ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection.   

Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined 
routinely; no transfusions were required. INR was checked POD1 
after coumadin was held POD0. It was restarted on his home 
dosing regimen POD1. Communication with his PCP who manages his 
coumadin as an outpatient was made prior to discharge and 
followup INR check and coumadin dosing was established. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

___ through ___ 
___. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
hold if having diarrhea 
13. Warfarin 5 mg PO 1X/WEEK (___) 
___ 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left carotid stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
WHAT TO EXPECT:

 

1. Surgical Incision:

·     It is normal to have some swelling and feel a firm ridge 
along the incision

·     Your incision may be slightly red and raised, it may feel 
irritated from the staples

2. You may have a sore throat and/or mild hoarseness

·     Try warm tea, throat lozenges or cool/cold beverages 

3. You may have a mild headache, especially on the side of your 
surgery

·     Try ibuprofen, acetaminophen, or your discharge pain 
medication

·     If headache worsens, is associated with visual changes or 
lasts longer than 2 hours- call vascular surgeons office

4. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 

·     You should get up out of bed every day and gradually 
increase your activity each day 

·     You may walk and you may go up and down stairs 

·     Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do 
too much right away!

5. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 

·     You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 

·     Eat small frequent meals

·     It is important to eat nutritious food options (high 
fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) 
to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing

·     To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

 

MEDICATION:

·     Take all of your medications as prescribed in your 
discharge 

ACTIVITIES:

 

·     No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer 
taking pain medications

·     No excessive head turning, lifting, pushing or pulling 
(greater than 5 lbs) until your post op visit

·     You may shower (no direct spray on incision, let the soapy 
water run over incision, rinse and pat dry)

·     Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

He has a history of CHF, afib, HTN, CVA, carotid stenosis, dyslipidemia, arthritis, bladder cancer, visual impairment, and hard of hearing. He has undergone several surgeries, including CABG x 3, AAA repair, AICD implant, and afib ablation.

The patient's presenting symptoms were a carotid bruit, and carotid noninvasive studies revealed a near total occlusion of his left carotid. He underwent a left carotid endarterectomy, which went well without complication.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, aspirin, digoxin, finasteride, metoprolol, pravastatin, tamsulosin, furosemide, lisinopril, and warfarin. He was also prescribed docusate sodium for bowel regularity.

The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his vascular surgeon and to take his medications as prescribed. He was advised to avoid driving until his post-op visit and to avoid excessive head turning, lifting, pushing, or pulling until his post-op visit. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman who initially presented 
with severe abdominal pain. At that time, no obvious findings on 
CT scan and no obvious leak was appreciated. Given her pain and 
significant CT findings, it was decided that she would benefit 
from a diagnostic laparoscopy. At that time, I was concerned 
that she may actually have a gastric perforation and may have a 
gallbladder issue that could potentially be addressed 
laparoscopically. Thus, we decided to start the case 
laparoscopically with potential conversion to an open procedure 
if a significant
lesion in the stomach was appreciated. The risks and benefits of 
the procedure were described in detail to the patient. Despite 
these risks, she chose to proceed with surgery. She was found to 
have a gastric perforation and therefore converted to 
exploratory laparotomy with ___ patch and placement of a 
Pravena vac. 

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; pain was initially managed with a IV dialudid 
PCA and then transitioned to oral acetaminophen and oxycodone 
once tolerating a diet. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO with a 
___ tube in place for decompression and nasojejunal 
tube in place for feeding.  On POD2 tube feeding were started 
through the doboff. On POD3 the NGT was accidently  removed by 
the patient when sneezing. She was kept NPO (except tube feeds). 
On POD5 she underwent upper GI leak test that was unclear and 
therefore was repeated on POD7 and negative for leak. Doboff was 
removed and she was given a regular diet with good tolerability. 
H.Pylori result was positive and therefore she was started on 
quadruple therapy once tolerating a diet. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none. H.Pylori quadrupal therapy 
started and prescribed 2 week course. 
HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Gastric perforation 
H. Pylori infction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital because you had abdominal 
pain. You had a CT scan which showed that you had a perforation 
in your stomach where it connects to your small intestine. It 
was found to be caused by an infection (H.pylori), for which you 
have been started on medication and will finish after discharge. 
You underwent surgery to get your perforation fixed. You have 
tolerated a regular diet, had a return of bowel function, and 
your pain has been well-controlled. Thus, you are now ready to 
be discharged home to continue your recovery. Please follow the 
discharge instructions below: 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

She also experienced severe abdominal pain, which began while she was sitting on the couch, and had not had a bowel movement or flatus in 2 days. She vomited non-bloody, non-bilious emesis shortly after eating.

The patient has no known allergies or adverse reactions. She has no past medical history, past surgical history, or family history of note.

The patient's physical examination revealed a soft, tender abdomen with focal rebound and guarding. Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy, which revealed a gastric perforation. She was converted to an exploratory laparotomy and underwent repair of the perforation with a patch and placement of a Pravena vac.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, but the specific medications are not mentioned in the report. ||endoftext||

She has a complicated past medical history, including a stroke with residual deficits, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, depression, and a total colectomy with ileostomy. She was recently readmitted from another hospital for a small bowel obstruction and underwent an exploratory laparotomy, left ostomy, and reduction of internal hernia, but unfortunately, the abdominal graft failed.

Upon presentation to the emergency department, the patient complained of abdominal pain around her ileostomy site and PEG tube site, as well as burning with urination. She was found to have hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia, hypercalcemia, and lactic acidosis, with concern for intraabdominal infection. She was started on insulin and antibiotics, and a CT abdomen showed nonspecific areas of low attenuation in the liver, which may be due to hepatic infarction or geographic fat.

The patient underwent several procedures, including G-tube placement and replacement, and was prescribed several medications, including insulin, antibiotics, and pain medication. She was also diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and was treated with antibiotics.

The patient's physical exam revealed a soft abdomen with tenderness around the PEG tube site and ileostomy site, as well as a left thigh skin wound. Her neurological exam showed residual deficits from her stroke, including right-sided hemiplegia. ||endoftext||

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 

You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
remembering new information.
Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 
Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Headaches:
Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain 
bleed. 
Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 
Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but 
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed 
by your doctor. 
There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs.

site.

Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake

Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience

Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were admitted to 
___.  You were hospitalized due to symptoms of left visual 
field cut resulting from a transient ischemic attack (a mini 
stroke), a condition in which a blood vessel providing oxygen 
and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is 
the part of your body that controls and directs all the other 
parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived 
of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
1) high cholesterol including cholesterol in your aorta (large 
vessel leaving your heart
2) high blood pressure
3) diabetes mellitus

We are changing your medications as follows:
1) START Plavix 75mg daily
2) DECREASE your Aspirin dose to only 81mg daily

Please take your other medications as prescribed.

Because of your visual problems last week, it is important for 
you to have a complete visual field test at your 
ophthalmologists office.  You CANNOT drive until you have this 
test completed and the results are approved by your 
ophthalmologist. 

Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.

___

||startoftext||The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted for evaluation of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and a right eye plaque. He has a history of syncope, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, diabetic retinopathy, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, gout, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has no history of neurologic conditions in his family. 

The patient's physical examination was normal, with no focal neurological deficits. His laboratory results showed elevated blood glucose and urea nitrogen levels, as well as mild right ventricular hypertrophy on echocardiogram. 

The patient's MRI brain was negative for stroke, and his MRA neck showed no evidence of high-grade stenosis or occlusion. He was diagnosed with a TIA and was started on dual antiplatelet therapy to reduce the risk of subsequent emboli. ||endoftext||
